title: Morphology-Specific Peptide Discovery via Masked Conditional Generative Modeling
summary:
Peptide self-assembly prediction offers a powerful bottom-up strategy for
designing biocompatible, low-toxicity materials for large-scale synthesis in a
broad range of biomedical and energy applications. However, screening the vast
sequence space for categorization of aggregate morphology remains intractable.
We introduce PepMorph, an end-to-end peptide discovery pipeline that generates
novel sequences that are not only prone to aggregate but self-assemble into a
specified fibrillar or spherical morphology. We compiled a new dataset by
leveraging existing aggregation propensity datasets and extracting geometric
and physicochemical isolated peptide descriptors that act as proxies for
aggregate morphology. This dataset is then used to train a Transformer-based
Conditional Variational Autoencoder with a masking mechanism, which generates
novel peptides under arbitrary conditioning. After filtering to ensure design
specifications and validation of generated sequences through coarse-grained
molecular dynamics simulations, PepMorph yielded 83% accuracy in intended
morphology generation, showcasing its promise as a framework for
application-driven peptide discovery.
tldr: This paper introduces PepMorph, a Transformer-based conditional variational autoencoder pipeline for generating novel peptide sequences that self-assemble into specified fibrillar or spherical morphologies, achieving 83% accuracy in intended morphology generation validated by molecular dynamics simulations.
explanation: The paper addresses the challenge of efficiently exploring the vast sequence space for peptide self-assembly with specific morphologies (fibrillar or spherical). It introduces PepMorph, a novel end-to-end pipeline that leverages a Transformer-based Conditional Variational Autoencoder with a masking mechanism. The model is trained on a new dataset combining aggregation propensity data and geometric/physicochemical descriptors as morphology proxies. Post-generation filtering and coarse-grained molecular dynamics simulations are used to validate the generated sequences, demonstrating 83% accuracy in achieving the target morphology. The masking mechanism allows flexible conditioning on various properties, and the pipeline shows promise for application-driven peptide discovery.
interests_alignment: This paper aligns strongly with my research interests. It focuses on peptide self-assembly and aggregation, uses machine learning (specifically, a Transformer-based VAE) for peptide design, and involves creating and utilizing a dataset relevant to peptide structure and aggregation. Furthermore, it employs computational simulation (molecular dynamics) to validate the generated peptides' assembly and morphology. The specific focus on morphology control is particularly relevant.
